newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: BHP continues to firm on steel shake-up.
newsitem.headline: BHP continues to firm on steel shake-up.

text.p: The shares of Australia's largest company, The Broken Hill Pty Co Ltd (BHP), continued to gain ground in mid-morning trade on Tuesday after it announced it would close its Newcastle steelworks.
At 11.20 a.m (0120 GMT), BHP shares were 27 cents higher at A$17.65 on turnover of 1.3 million shares.
"It's reacting to the announcements that were made this morning. The tightening-up of the steel division," said Kevin Lourey a dealer at Melbourne-base broker, Peake Lands Kirwan.
Lourey said the market was interpreting the changes as a decision by BHP to improve its earnings.
"I think it (BHP's share price) will now move back towards A$18.00. I think it's got further to go," Lourey said.
In a widely-expected announcement, BHP said it would phase-out steel making at its major Newcastle plant by the end of 1999 and also close its Geelong rod mill and Sydney wire mill in the same year.
Another Melbourne-based broker said the news was very positive for the company but some investors were treading Carefully until they saw the reaction of unions to the changes.
